I'm not sure if NEAT or HyperNEAT have been used in this area as I've been
=
working in a different area with it, but I would imagine OpenCV would be a
=
good first place to look for objection recognition or computer vision. Not
=
sure what the "state of the art" is however.

Perhaps use OpenCV for some i=
nitial data filtering to reduce noise, and then
feed the data into evolutio=
nary neural nets. I'm not sure if the opencv
implementation comes with anyt=
hing besides feed-forward 3 layer neural
nets.

pan>=A0</span>


<div>

    <div>
      
      
      <p>I've =
seen quite a bit of material on using NEAT for robotic control and more rec=
ently using CPPNs for evolving robot morphology, but I don't recall see=
ing anything being done in the area of perception and understanding / world=
 modeling alone.  Is anyone working in this area?  I realize that for most =
of the robot control, there is implied perception - that is, mapping some a=
spects of a world through a NN-based policy to actions - but what I'm i=
nterested in is doing things like object recognition or something along the=
 lines of more traditional computer vision.<br>


<br>
Also, if anyone is w=
illing to collaborate on this or any other NEAT-related efforts in robotics=
, I'd love to talk to you.  I'm trying to drum up support for doing=
 research in evolutionary robotics at my lab (Lockheed Martin Advanced Tech=
nology Labs' Intelligent Robotics Lab).  It's been a subject I'=
ve long been interested in, but have never had much opportunity to actually=
 work on outside of my own side probjects and school.<br>


<br>
-- Chris<b=
r>
<br>
</p>

    </div>

t:0"></div>
